Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master KumÄrajÄ«va of Kucha in the Later Qin Those who contemplate the Dharma should contemplate as the Buddha has expounded:
This Dharma is skillfully expounded, attains the fruit of this world, is free from vexation, does not depend on time, is able to reach a good place, and is unobstructed.
Skillfully expounded means that the two truths are not contradictory, namely the conventional truth and the ultimate truth.
The wise cannot destroy it, and the foolish do not dispute it.
This Dharma is also free from the two extremes, namely the enjoyment of the five desires and the practice of austerities.
It is also free from the two extremes:
eternalism, nihilism, self, non-self, existence, and non-existence.
Not attached to such dualistic extremes is called skillfully expounded.
The non-Buddhists value their own teachings and denigrate the teachings of others, and therefore they are not able to skillfully expound.

Attaining the fruits of this very world means being free from the causes and conditions of craving and the various sufferings of the world, and being free from the causes and conditions of wrong views and various debates and disputes, so that one's body and mind can attain peace and joy.
As the Buddha said:
Those who uphold the precepts are at ease, their body and mind are not troubled,
They sleep peacefully and wake peacefully, and their fame spreads far and wide.

Furthermore, in this Buddhist teaching, fruits are produced through the continuous succession of causes and conditions, namely: because one upholds the precepts purely, one's mind does not regret; because the mind does not regret, one gives rise to the joy of the Dharma; because one is joyful in the Dharma, one's body and mind are at ease; because one's body and mind are at ease, one is able to concentrate the mind; because the mind is concentrated, one knows things as they really are; because one knows things as they really are, one attains disenchantment; because one attains disenchantment, one becomes free from desire; because one becomes free from desire, one attains liberation; attaining the fruits of liberation, one attains nirvana - this is called attaining the fruits of this very world.
The practices of non-Buddhists are empty and painful, and they attain nothing.
As an arhat in JambudvÄ«pa said when he attained the Way:
I was once a non-Buddhist practitioner for fifty-five years,
only eating dried cow dung, naked, and sleeping on thorns.
I underwent such hardship, but in the end, I gained nothing;
not like now, where I have seen the Buddha, heard the Dharma, left the household life for three days, accomplished what needed to be done, and attained arhatship.
Therefore, we know that the Buddha's teachings bring about results in this very life.
Question:
If the Buddha's teachings bring about results in this very life, why is it that among the Buddha's disciples, there are those who do not attain anything?
Answer:
If practitioners practice in sequence according to what the Buddha has taught, there is no one who does not receive the reward;
it is like a patient who follows the doctor's instructions and takes the prescribed medicine, and there is no illness that cannot be cured.

If one does not follow the Buddha's teachings, does not practice in sequence, breaks the precepts, and is distracted in mind, then one will not attain anything, but it is not that the Dharma is ineffective.

Furthermore, those who have not yet attained the Way may not attain nirvana in this life, but in future lives they will receive the bliss of blessings and gradually attain nirvana, which will never be in vain.
As the Buddha said:
Those who leave the household life to attain nirvana, whether slowly or quickly, will all attain nirvana.
In this way, one can attain the fruits of this very life.
Free from distress means there are two kinds of distress:
bodily distress and mental distress.
Bodily distress refers to being bound, imprisoned, beaten, and executed, etc.
Mental distress refers to the causes and conditions of lust, anger, stinginess, greed, and jealousy, which give rise to worry, fear, and so forth.
In this Buddha-Dharma, because one observes the precepts purely, the body is free from the distress of being bound, imprisoned, beaten, and executed, etc.;
Because the mind is free from the five desires, removes the five hindrances, and attains the true path, there is no vexation of lust, anger, stinginess, greed, jealousy, wrong views, and so forth.
Because there is no vexation, there is no heat.
Furthermore, the joy and bliss born from the uncontaminated dhyÄna concentration are experienced throughout the body, so all heat is removed;
it is like a person who is greatly heated and confused, but upon entering a cool and refreshing pool, becomes cool and clear, and no longer has any heat or vexation.
Furthermore, afflictions that belong to views or belong to craving are called heat;
because the Buddha's teachings are free from these, they are called free from vexation and heat.
Not waiting for the right time means that the Buddha's teachings are practiced without waiting for the right time, and also do not wait for the right time to give results.
The teachings of non-Buddhists are received when the sun has not yet risen, but not received when the sun has risen;
some are received when the sun has risen, but not received when the sun has not yet risen;
some are received during the day but not received at night, and some are received at night but not received during the day.
In the Buddha's teachings, there is no acceptance of waiting for the right time. Following the cultivation of the eightfold noble path, one immediately attains nirvana.
It is like fire that burns when it gets fuel;
When the uncontaminated wisdom arises, it can immediately burn away all afflictions, not waiting for the right time.
Question:
As the Buddha said, there are timely medicine, timely clothing, and timely food;
If a person's wholesome roots are not yet mature, they must wait for the right time to attain [nirvana]. Why is it said that there is no right time?
Answer:
This right time is in accordance with worldly conventions. In order for the Buddha's teachings to remain for a long time, timely precepts are established;
If it is for cultivating the path to attain nirvana, as well as various meditative absorptions and the subtle Dharma of wisdom, it does not wait for the right time.
The teachings of non-Buddhists all wait for the right time, but the Buddha's teachings only wait for the conditions to be complete.
Even if one observes precepts and practices meditation, if the wisdom is not yet accomplished, one cannot attain the path;
If one perfects moral discipline, meditation, and wisdom, one attains the fruits and no longer needs to wait for the right time.
Moreover, if it takes a long time to attain the fruits, it is called time, but if it is attained immediately, it is not called time.
It is like dyeing a good cloth, which is completed in one step;
the mind of a pure person is also like this. Hearing the Dharma, one is immediately dyed and attains the purity of the Dharma eye. This is called not waiting for the right time.
Able to reach a good place refers to the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, which can lead one to nirvana;
it is like entering the Ganges River, one will surely reach the great ocean.
The teachings of other non-Buddhists were spoken by those who lack omniscience and are mixed with wrong views, so they lead to an evil place;
sometimes they lead to the heavens, but one falls back and suffers, all because they are impermanent, so they are not called a good place.
Question:
Since there is no one who leads, how can one be led to a good place?
Answer:
Although there is no one who takes them away, the dharmas are able to take the dharmas away;
The five wholesome aggregates of the uncontaminated path cut off the five aggregates. Among the five aggregates, the strong one is called a sentient being, which is taken away and enters nirvana.
It is like wind blowing dust, like water floating grass;
Although there is no one who takes them away, they can still be taken away.

Moreover, in the combination of causes and conditions, there is no action, and there is no one who takes them away, yet the fruits and retributions belong to the causes and conditions, and they are not independent. This is called going.
Penetrating without obstruction means that because one attains the seal of the Buddha's teachings, one penetrates without obstruction;
It is like obtaining the royal seal, then there is nothing to obstruct.
Question:
What are the seals of the Buddha's teachings?
Answer:
There are three kinds of seals of the Buddha's teachings:
First, all conditioned dharmas arise and cease moment by moment, and are all impermanent. Second, all dharmas are without self. Third, nirvana is quiescent extinction.

Practitioners know that the three realms are all conditioned dharmas of arising and ceasing. They were not before and are now, are now and will not be later. Moment by moment, arising and ceasing, they continue in a similar sequence, so they can be seen and known.
Like flowing water, a lamp flame, and a long wind, they continue in a similar sequence, so people take them to be one.
Sentient beings, due to the constant inversion regarding impermanent dharmas, take the goer to be permanently abiding.
This is called the seal of the impermanence of all conditioned dharmas.
All dharmas are without self:

Within the dharmas, there is no master, no doer, no cognition, no seeing, no one who gives rise, and no creator. All dharmas belong to causes and conditions. Because they belong to causes and conditions, they are not independent. Because they are not independent, they are without self. Because the characteristics of self cannot be apprehended, as explained in the chapter on refuting self - this is called the seal of no-self.
Question:
Why are only conditioned dharmas impermanent and all dharmas without self?
Answer:
Because the unconditioned does not arise or cease without causes and conditions,
it is not called impermanent.
Moreover, in the unconditioned, one does not give rise to inverted attachment to the mind. For this reason, it is not said to be impermanent, but it can be said to be non-self.
Some say:
The spirit is the characteristic of permanence and omnipresence.
For this reason, it is said that there is no self in all dharmas.
Quiescent extinction refers to nirvÄá¹‡a, because the fires of the three poisons and the three calamities are extinguished, it is called the seal of quiescent extinction.
Question:
Why are there only one dharma and not many in the seal of quiescent extinction?
Answer:

In the first seal, the five aggregates are discussed. In the second seal, it is said that all dharmas are without self. In the third seal, the fruits of the two seals are discussed. This is called the seal of quiescent extinction.
All conditioned dharmas are impermanent, which breaks down the external five desires and so forth that one grasps as one's own;
If one speaks of non-self, it breaks down the internal dharmas that one grasps as one's own self;
Because of the destruction of self and what belongs to self, this is called the quiescent nirvana.
The practitioner contemplates conditioned dharmas as impermanent, and thus gives rise to disgust, and disgust with the suffering of the world.

Having already understood disgust with suffering, they cling to the contemplator, thinking I am the one who contemplates in this way. For this reason, there is a second Dharma seal, which is to know that all is without self.
Within the five aggregates, twelve sense fields, eighteen elements, and twelve links of dependent arising, one internally and externally analyzes and seeks, but the contemplator cannot be found.
Because it cannot be found, all dharmas are without self.
Having understood this, one does not engage in conceptual proliferation, has no basis to rely on, and simply returns to cessation. For this reason, it is said to be the seal of the quiescent nirvana.
Question:

In the MahÄyÄna, it is said that all dharmas are unborn and unceasing, of one mark, which is to say, no mark. Why is it said here that the impermanence of all conditioned dharmas is called the Dharma seal?
How can these two dharmas be non-contradictory?
Answer:
Contemplating impermanence is precisely contemplating emptiness and conditions;
Just as contemplating form's moment-to-moment impermanence, one knows it to be empty.
Past form is destroyed and cannot be seen, so it has no form characteristics;
Future form is unborn, without action or function, and cannot be seen, so it has no form characteristics;
Present form also has no abiding, cannot be seen, and cannot be distinguished and known, so it has no form characteristics.
The absence of form characteristics is precisely emptiness, and emptiness is precisely non-arising and non-ceasing.
Non-arising and non-ceasing, and arising and ceasing, are in reality one, with extensive and concise explanations.
Question:
Past and future forms cannot be seen, so they have no form characteristics. Present forms can be seen when abiding. Why say they have no form characteristics?
Answer:
Present forms also have no abiding time. As explained in the Four Foundations of Mindfulness:
If a dharma is seen to be destroyed later, you should know that it was destroyed when it first arose, but because it follows subtle [changes] it is not recognized.
It is like a person wearing sandals. If they are new on the first day and have no oldness, they should always be new later and should not have oldness.
If there is no oldness, they should be permanent. Because of permanence, there is no sin and no merit. Because of no sin and no merit, the laws of the path and the laity would be in chaos.
Furthermore, the characteristics of arising and ceasing always follow conditioned dharmas, and there is no time of abiding.
If there were a time of abiding, then there would be no arising and ceasing.
For this reason, present form has no abiding.
Within abiding, there is also no arising and ceasing. Because this single thought of abiding is also a conditioned dharma, this is called penetrating without obstruction.
One should contemplate the Dharma in this way.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of Dharma:
The first is the three baskets, twelve divisions, and eighty-four thousand aggregates of the Dharma expounded by the Buddha;
Second, the meaning of the Dharma taught by the Buddha, namely, precepts, meditation, wisdom, the eightfold noble path, the fruits of liberation, nirvana, and so forth.
Practitioners should first contemplate what the Buddha has expounded, and next contemplate the meaning of the Dharma.
Contemplating what the Buddha has expounded means that the Buddha's words are beautiful and wonderful, all true, and of great benefit.
What the Buddha has expounded is both profound and shallow:
Profound because it contemplates the true nature, shallow because it skillfully explains.
Repeating words without error, each having its own meaning.
What the Buddha has expounded abides in four places, adorned with four kinds of merits:
First, the place of wisdom, second, the place of truth, third, the place of abandonment, fourth, the place of cessation.
There are four kinds of answers, therefore it is indestructible:
First, definite answer, second, analytical answer, third, counter-question answer, fourth, inconclusive answer.
The Buddha's teachings sometimes allow and then prohibit, sometimes prohibit and then allow, sometimes allow without prohibiting, and sometimes prohibit without allowing;
all four are in accordance with and without contradiction.
The Buddha speaks of attaining the characteristics of all dharmas, thus being free from conceptual proliferation;
because of speaking with meaning and principle, he refutes existence and non-existence.
The Buddha's teachings accord with the ultimate truth. Although he speaks of worldly dharmas, there is no fault, because they are not in contradiction with the two truths.
In accordance with beneficial teachings, among pure people it is delightful, among impure people it is painful and unpleasant;
among pleasant speech and painful speech, there is also no fault.
The Buddha's words all accord with wholesome dharmas, yet he is not attached to wholesome dharmas.
Although they are defiled dharmas and adversaries, he does not consider them superior;
although he reproaches various things, there is also no fault in his reproaches;
although he praises various dharmas, he also has no basis for attachment.
In the Buddha's words, there is neither increase nor decrease, whether concise or extensive.
The Buddha's words are good in the beginning, and good if sought for a long time.
Although the Buddha's words are numerous, their meaning is not shallow.
Although there are various mixed words, their meaning is not confused.
Although they can attract people's minds, they do not cause people to give rise to attachment.
Although they are extraordinary and lofty, they do not make people feel fearful.
Although they reach everywhere, ordinary people cannot understand them.
The Buddha's words have such various rare things, which can make people's hair stand on end, their pores sweat, their bodies tremble with fear;
They can also cause the minds of the devas to be disgusted, filling the ten directions with sound, and shaking the earth in six ways;
They can also cause people to abandon what they have clung to in the world without beginning, and to delight in what they have not clung to.
When evil people hear the Buddha's words, they are worried, frightened, and distressed because of their own sins;
When people who are diligently and single-mindedly progressing on the path hear it, it is like taking the taste of nectar, which is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end.

Furthermore, in a large assembly, each person wants to hear something. The Buddha answers with a single statement, and each person understands and each person sees the Buddha speaking exclusively to them.

Although there may be far and near in the great assembly, those who hear it do not perceive the sound as increasing or decreasing, filling the trichiliocosm, up to the immeasurable worlds in the ten directions;
Those who are to be liberated hear it, while those who are not to be liberated do not hear it;
It is like thunder shaking the earth, which the deaf do not hear, while those who can hear are enlightened.
In this way, various thoughts arise regarding the Buddha's words.
What is the meaning of the Dharma?
Faith, precepts, giving, hearing, concentration, wisdom, and other wholesome dharmas, as well as the three Dharma seals, are as explained in the Penetration chapter.
All conditioned dharmas are impermanent, all dharmas are without self, and nirvÄá¹‡a is quiescent. This is called the meaning of the Buddha Dharma.
These three seals cannot be destroyed by any logicians. Although there are various extensive explanations, no one can change the nature of dharmas;
Just as the characteristic of coldness cannot be changed to heat.
The nature of dharmas cannot be destroyed. Even if a person can injure space, these dharma seals cannot be destroyed according to the Dharma.
The sages know these three kinds of dharma characteristics and are free from all places of reliance on wrong views and various disputes;
It is like a person with eyes seeing a group of blind people arguing about various colors, feeling pity and smiling, not arguing with them.
Question:
The Buddha taught that in the Å›rÄvaka teachings there are four kinds of truth, and in the MahÄyÄna there is one truth. Why are three truths taught now?
Answer:
The Buddha taught three kinds of true dharma seals, which are extensively explained as four kinds and concisely explained as one kind.

Impermanence is precisely the truth of suffering, the truth of accumulation, and the truth of the path. Speaking of non-self includes all dharmas. Speaking of quiescent extinction nirvÄá¹‡a is precisely the truth of cessation.
Furthermore, conditioned dharmas are impermanent, arising and ceasing moment by moment, and therefore all belong to causes and conditions, without independence;
without independence, there is no self;
impermanence, no-self, and no characteristics cause the mind not to be attached. Because of not being attached to characteristics, it is precisely quiescent extinction nirvÄá¹‡a.

For this reason, although the MahÄyÄna teaches that all dharmas are unborn and unceasing, of one characteristic, namely no characteristics, no characteristics are precisely quiescent extinction nirvÄá¹‡a.
This mindfulness of dharmas samÄdhi takes wisdom and extinction as objects, and the merits of bodhisattvas and pratyekabuddhas.
Question:ğŸ”½Why is it that the mindfulness of the Buddha only takes the dharmas of no-more-learning in the Buddha's body as objects?
The mindfulness of the Saá¹…gha samÄdhi takes the dharmas of learning and no-more-learning in the Buddha's disciples' bodies as objects?
Are the remaining wholesome and pure dharmas all the objects of the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Dharma?
Answer:
KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra says this.
The MahÄyÄna people say:

The Buddhas of the three times and ten directions, and the merits and spiritual powers created by the Buddhas from their initial arousal of the mind until the end of the Dharma, are all the objects of the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Buddha.

The meaning of the sÅ«tras spoken by the Buddha, from a single sentence or verse up to the eighty-four thousand aggregates of the Dharma, the wholesome dharmas such as faith, morality, giving, hearing, concentration, wisdom, and so forth, up to nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder, are all the objects of the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Dharma.

The assemblies of bodhisattvas, pratyekabuddhas, and Å›rÄvakas, excluding the Buddha, and the merits of all the noble assemblies and the wholesome dharmas, are the objects of the samÄdhi of mindfulness of the Saá¹…gha.

Recollecting the Sangha refers to the assembly of the Buddha's disciples, who are fully endowed with the aggregate of morality, the aggregate of concentration, the aggregate of wisdom, the aggregate of liberation, and the aggregate of the knowledge and vision of liberation;
the four pairs and eight assemblies, who are worthy of receiving offerings, respect, and veneration, and are the unsurpassed field of merit in the world.
The practitioner should recollect the Sangha as praised by the Buddha:
whether it be the assembly of Å›rÄvakas, the assembly of pratyekabuddhas, or the assembly of bodhisattvas, their merits are to be praised.
This noble Sangha is fully endowed with the five aggregates, as explained above.
Question:
Since the five aggregates have already been used to praise the Buddha, why are they again used to praise the Sangha?
Answer:
It praises their completeness according to the five aggregates attained by the disciples.
Completeness is of two kinds:
first, actual completeness; second, nominal completeness.ğŸ”½Praising them as having attained all that should be attained by the Buddha's disciples is called nominal completeness;
praising them as having attained what the Buddha has attained is called actual completeness.
Furthermore, in order to distinguish itself from the non-Buddhist renunciant and lay communities, it praises in this way.
The non-Buddhist lay communities praise their wealth, nobility, and power;
the renunciant communities praise their heretical views, ascetic practices, attachment to wisdom, and contentious debates.
Thinking of the monastic community, some may have incomplete precepts, meditation, wisdom, etc., which are not worthy of praise;
Therefore, the Buddha himself praises his disciples' community, the fundamental abode of all merits, complete in the precepts, up to complete in liberation and wisdom.

Abiding in this community of precepts without wavering, drawing the bow of meditation and releasing the arrow of wisdom, one can destroy the thieves of afflictions and attain liberation. Within this liberation, one gives rise to wisdom.
It is like a strong man who first stabilizes his footing, draws his bow, and releases his arrow, able to defeat his enemies and escape from two fears:
Avoiding punishment from the king and rescuing himself from the battlefield;
Having decisively understood and seen, the thief has already been destroyed. The mind gives rise to joy. Therefore, with the five aggregates, one praises.
Those who should be worshipped are those whose virtues of the five aggregates are complete.
It is like a wealthy and powerful person whom others respect and admire;

The assembly of the Buddha's disciples is also like this. They have the wealth of pure precepts, meditation, and wisdom, and the power of liberation and the knowledge and insight of liberation. Therefore, they should be worshipped, respected, and served with palms joined in respect.
The unsurpassed field of merit in the world refers to the two kinds of donors:
The poor and the wealthy.
The poor receive offerings, respect, and service, and thus attain rewards;
The wealthy are also able to make offerings, respect, and serve with palms joined in respect, and thus attain rewards. Therefore, they are called the unsurpassed field of merit in the world.
It is like a good field that is well-ploughed and well-prepared. If seeds are sown in it at the right time and watered abundantly, the harvest will certainly be great.
The field of merit of the Saá¹…gha is also like this. Using the plow of wisdom, they plow out the roots of afflictions, and refine and tame them with the four immeasurables.

The offerings of the donors, like seeds, are watered with the water of mindfulness, generosity, respect, and pure thoughts. In this life and the next, they attain immeasurable worldly happiness and the fruits of the Three Vehicles.

Like the bhiká¹£u Bakkula, during the time of Buddha Vipashyin, he offered a single harÄ«takÄ« fruit to the Saá¹…gha. For ninety-one eons, he enjoyed the fruits of blessings in the heavens and among humans, always free from illness;
Now, he encountered ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha, went forth, ended his defilements, and attained arhatship.

Like the Å›ramaá¹‡a VÄ«radatta, during the time of Buddha Vipashyin, he built a single dwelling, covered the ground with materials, and offered it to the Saá¹…gha. For ninety-one eons, he enjoyed the fruits of blessings in the heavens and among humans, his feet never touching the ground;
When born, the hair on the soles of his feet was two inches long, soft and pure.
His father was delighted and gave him twenty billion taels of gold.
Seeing the Buddha and hearing the Dharma, he attained arhatship and was foremost among the disciples in diligence.
Thus, giving a little brings great rewards. Therefore, it is called the unsurpassed field of blessings in the world.

As for the Sangha consisting of four pairs and eight categories, the reason the Buddha speaks of it as the unsurpassed field of blessings in the world is because it contains these eight categories of noble ones, and is therefore called the unsurpassed field of blessings.
Question:
As the Buddha told the Elder AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada:
There are two kinds of fields of blessings in the world who should be honored and offered to:
those in training and those beyond training;
there are eighteen for those in training and nine for those beyond training.
Why are only eight mentioned here now?
Answer:
Because it is explained in detail there, there are eighteen and nine, but here it is explained concisely, so there are eight;
the twenty-seven noble ones are all included in these eight.

Faith-followers and Dharma-followers may be included in those heading towards the stream-enterer stage, or those heading towards the once-returner stage, or those heading towards the non-returner stage;
those of the family-to-family type are included in those heading towards the once-returner stage;
those of the one-intervener type are included in those heading towards the non-returner stage;
the five types of non-returners are included in those heading towards the arhat stage;

faith-followers and Dharma-followers who enter the path of contemplation are called faith-liberated and view-attained, and these faith-liberated and view-attained are included in the fifteen types of learners;
the nine types of fields of merit are included in the arhats.

Moreover, practitioners should contemplate the Saá¹…gha, thinking, The Saá¹…gha is the true companion on my path to nirvÄá¹‡a. With the same precepts and the same views, I should joyfully and single-mindedly respect and follow them without contradiction.
Previously, my companions were various kinds of evil, such as wife, children, slaves, and people, who were companions leading me into the three evil paths;
Now I have attained the companions of the sages, and I will peacefully reach nirvÄá¹‡a.
The Buddha is like the king of physicians, the Dharma is like good medicine, and the Saá¹…gha is like the attendant to the sick.
I should uphold the precepts purely and have right mindfulness, and follow the Dharma medicine taught by the Buddha.
The Saá¹…gha is one of the causes and conditions for me to sever the illness of the afflictions, namely the attendant to the sick, therefore I should remember the Saá¹…gha.
Moreover, the Saá¹…gha is endowed with immeasurable precepts, meditative concentration, wisdom, and so forth, and its virtues are immeasurable.
It is like a wealthy and noble elder who had faith and joy in the Saá¹…gha. He said to the Saá¹…gha's steward:
I invite the Saá¹…gha to a meal in my house in order.
He invited them in turn every day, even inviting the novice monks. The steward did not allow the novice monks to accept the invitation.
The novice monks said:
What is the reason for not allowing the novice monks?
He replied:
Because the donor does not like to invite the young.
Then he spoke a verse, saying:
Hair and beard white as snow, teeth fallen, skin and flesh wrinkled,
With a hunched gait and a weak body, they are happy to invite such people.
The Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras were all great arhats. Like striking a lion's head, they suddenly rose from their seats and spoke a verse, saying:
The donor is an ignorant person who sees form but does not take virtue.
Abandoning this youthful appearance, he only takes the old, emaciated, and dark!
As for the appearance of the most venerable elders, the Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
So-called old age does not necessarily come with advanced years.
A withered form with white beard and hair is just empty old age without inner virtue.
Able to abandon the fruits of sin and merit, diligently practicing the holy life,
Already free from all dharmas, this is called old age.
At that time, the Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras had another thought:
We should not sit idly by and watch this donor judge the good and bad of the saá¹ƒgha.
They then spoke another verse, saying:
In praise and scolding, our minds are indeed one;
This person slanders the Buddha's teachings, we should not fail to instruct him!
We should quickly go to his house and teach him with the Dharma,
Those whom we do not liberate, are then abandoned.

The Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras then transformed their bodies, all becoming elderly, with white hair like snow, bushy eyebrows hanging over their eyes, wrinkled skin like waves, their spines curved like bows, their two hands supporting a staff as they walked, in order to accept the invitation;
Their entire bodies trembled, their walking and sitting were not at ease, like a white poplar tree, swaying with the wind.
The layperson saw this group and joyfully welcomed them to sit down;
After sitting for a while, they returned to their youthful forms.
The layperson was frightened and said:
Such an appearance of old age, returning to a youthful body;
It's like taking a pill to restore youth - how could this be so?
The novice monks said:
Do not give rise to doubt and fear, we are not non-humans.
You want to measure the Saá¹…gha, this matter is very regrettable!
We show this transformation out of pity for you, you should deeply recognize it, the noble Saá¹…gha is immeasurable!
As it is said:
It is like using a mosquito's wings, one can still measure the bottom of the ocean;
All gods and humans, there is no one who can measure the Saá¹…gha.
The Saá¹…gha is precious because of its merit, it is still not distinguished;
But you use age to measure the great virtues.
Greatness and smallness arise from wisdom, not from old or young.ğŸ”½There is wisdom and diligent effort, although young, they are old;
Lazy and without wisdom, although old, they are young.
You now want to measure the Sangha, this is a great mistake!
If you want to measure the bottom of the great ocean with one finger, you will be laughed at by the wise!
Have you not heard the Buddha say:
'There are four things that, although small, should not be slighted?
Although a prince is small, he will become the king of a country, and should not be slighted;
Although a snake's child is small, its poison can kill a person, and should not be slighted;
Although a small fire is tiny, it can burn mountains and fields, and should not be slighted;
Although a novice monk is small, he has attained the holy spiritual powers, and should be most respected!'
There are also four kinds of people who are like the mango fruit:
Some are born looking ripe, some are ripe looking unripe, some are born looking unripe, and some are ripe looking ripe.
The Buddha's disciples are also like this:ğŸ”½Some have attained the holy virtues but their deportment and speech do not resemble those of good people;
Some resemble good people in deportment and speech but have not attained the holy virtues;
Some have deportment and speech that do not resemble those of good people, and have not yet accomplished the holy merits;
Some have deportment and speech that resemble those of good people, and have accomplished the holy merits.
Why do you not heed these words, yet wish to measure the Saá¹…gha?
If you wish to slander the Saá¹…gha, then you are slandering yourself. You have made a great mistake!
The past cannot be pursued, but from now on, with a wholesome mind, remove all doubts and regrets, and listen to what I say:
The holy assembly is immeasurable, difficult to know by deportment,
Not by clan or surname, nor by much learning,
Not by dignity and virtue, nor by seniority,
Not by dignified appearance, nor by eloquent speech.
The holy assembly is like the great ocean, its merits are extremely deep.
The Buddha praises the Saá¹…gha with a hundred things. Although the offering is small, the reward is great.
This is the third treasure, whose sound is heard far and wide, and for this reason one should make offerings to the Saá¹…gha.
One should not discriminate between old and young, those with much knowledge and those with little learning, or the bright and the dim;
Just as when a person looks at a forest, one does not discriminate between the thorny cassia, champak, and sÄla trees.
If you wish to think of the Saá¹…gha, you should be like this, and should not use foolishness to discriminate against the sages.
When MahÄkÄÅ›yapa went forth, he paid one hundred thousand gold coins for a robe,
Wishing to make a lowly garment for a beggar, but no matter how hard he searched, he could not find anything coarse and worn.
The Saá¹…gha of sages is also like this, seeking the smallest field of blessings,
Able to repay the donor ten thousand times, but if one seeks further, it cannot be found.
The Saá¹…gha is like the great ocean, with precepts as its boundary.
If there are those who break the precepts, they will never be counted among the Saá¹…gha;
It is just like the great ocean, which does not coexist with a corpse!
The patron, hearing this and seeing this supernatural power, was startled and his hair stood on end. He joined his palms and said to the novice monks:
Noble ones, I now repent!
I am an ordinary person whose mind is always full of offenses. I have a small doubt and now wish to ask about it.
And he spoke a verse, saying:
The Venerable Ones have already transcended doubt, and I now have the opportunity to meet you.
If I do not ask about it again, then I would be the most foolish of the foolish!
The novice monks said:
If you wish to ask, then ask. We will answer according to what we have heard.
The patron asked:
With pure faith in the Buddha-Jewel and pure faith in the Sangha-Jewel, which brings greater blessings?
He replied:
We have never seen the Sangha-Jewel or the Buddha-Jewel increase or decrease.
Why is it so?
Once the Buddha was begging for alms in ÅšrÄvastÄ«. There was a brÄhman named VÄsiá¹£á¹­ha who often came to his house to beg for food.
He thought in his mind:
Why does this Å›ramaá¹‡a come so often, as if he owes him a debt?
The Buddha then spoke a verse:
When the rain falls frequently, the five grains are harvested frequently;
Frequently cultivating meritorious deeds, one frequently receives the fruits of retribution.
Frequently receiving the Dharma of birth, one thus frequently experiences death;
The sage's Dharma is frequently accomplished, who would frequently be born and die?
When the brÄhman heard this verse, he thought:
The Buddha is a great sage who fully knows my mind.
Feeling ashamed, he took the bowl into the house, filled it with delicious food, and offered it to the Buddha.
The Buddha did not accept it and said:
I obtained this food because I spoke a verse. I will not eat it!
The brÄhmaá¹‡a said:
To whom should this food be given?
The Buddha said:
I do not see any god or human who can digest this food. Take it away and place it on the ground with little grass or in water without insects!
In accordance with the Buddha's instructions, he took the food and placed it in water without insects. The water immediately boiled, and smoke and fire arose together, as if it were a great hot iron.
Seeing this, the brÄhmaá¹‡a was frightened and said:
Never before has there been such a thing!
Even the spiritual power in the food is like this!
He returned to where the Buddha was, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, repented, and asked to go forth and receive the precepts.
The Buddha said:
Welcome!
Immediately his beard and hair fell out by themselves, and he became a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Gradually severing the bonds, he attained the path of arhatship.
Furthermore, MahÄprajÄpatÄ« offered the Buddha a golden upper and lower robe.
The Buddha knew that the Sangha was capable of using it, and told GautamÄ«:
Give this upper and lower robe to the Sangha.
For this reason, we know that the merit of the Buddha Jewel and the Sangha Jewel is immeasurable.
The donors said:
If the Sangha can digest and accept what is given for the Buddha, why did the Buddha not allow the Sangha to eat the food offered by the brÄhmaá¹‡a VÄrada?
The novice monks replied:
It is to show the great power of the Sangha.
If one does not see the great spiritual power in the water, one cannot know that the power of the Sangha is great!
If the Sangha can accept what is given for the Buddha, then one knows that the power of the Sangha is great.
It is like a doctor who wants to test poison. He first gives it to a chicken, and the chicken dies immediately, and then he takes it himself. Only then does he know that the doctor's power is great!
Therefore, donors should know:
If one loves and respects the Buddha, one should also love and respect the Sangha,
One should not make distinctions, because they are all equally precious.
At that time, the patron heard these words and joyfully said:
I, so-and-so, from this day forward, if there are those who enter the ranks of the Saá¹…gha, whether young or old, I will single-mindedly believe and respect them, not daring to make distinctions!
The novice monks said:
Your mind believes and respects the unsurpassed field of merit. Before long, you will attain the Way.
Why is it so?
'Those of much learning and those who uphold the precepts, those of wisdom and those in meditative concentration,
All enter the ranks of the Saá¹…gha, like myriad streams returning to the ocean.
Just as all medicinal herbs rely on the snow-capped mountains,
And all grains, grasses, and trees rely on the earth,
All good people are included in the ranks of the Saá¹…gha!
Moreover, have you ever heard the Buddha praise the three good men - Aniruddha, Nandi, and Kashyapa - as the generals of the long ghosts?
The Buddha said:
If all the worlds, gods and humans, single-mindedly think of the three good men, they will obtain immeasurable benefits for a long time.
For this reason, you should double your faith and respect the Sangha!
These three people are not called the Sangha. The Buddha said that thinking of the three people has such fruits and rewards, let alone single-mindedly and purely thinking of the Sangha!
Therefore, donor!
You should single-mindedly think of the names of the Sangha to the best of your ability!
As it is said in the verse:
This assembly of sages is a valiant army,
Crushing the demon king's thieves, this companion reaches nirvana!
The novice monks spoke various holy merits of the Sangha to the donor.
After the donor heard this, the entire family, young and old, all saw the four truths and attained the path of stream-entry.
For this reason, one should single-mindedly contemplate the Sangha.
As for contemplating precepts, there are two kinds of precepts:
defiled precepts and undefiled precepts.
Defiled precepts are also of two kinds:
first, precepts of restraint, and second, precepts shared with concentration.
When practitioners first study, they contemplate these three kinds of precepts;
after studying the three kinds, they only contemplate the undefiled precepts.
These precepts of restraint can prevent evil from becoming rampant, withered, and diminished, while the precepts of concentration can restrain afflictions.
Why is this?
Because one attains inner joy, one does not seek worldly pleasures.
The undefiled precepts can uproot the roots of evil afflictions.
A question is asked:
How does one contemplate the precepts?
The answer is:

As explained earlier in the contemplation of the Sangha, the Buddha is like the king of physicians, the Dharma is like good medicine, the Sangha is like the attendant to the patient, and the precepts are like the taboos when taking medicine;
The practitioner thinks to himself:
If I do not follow the prohibitions, the Three Jewels will not benefit me.
Moreover, it is like a guide pointing out the good path, but the traveler does not use it, and the guide is not at fault. For this reason, I should contemplate the precepts.
Furthermore, this precept is the abode of all wholesome dharmas;
It is like the hundred grains and medicinal trees that grow based on the earth.
Upholding the precepts purely can give rise to and develop profound dhyÄna concentrations and the wisdom of the true aspect;
It is also the initial gate for renunciant practitioners, the reliance of all renunciant practitioners, and the initial cause for attaining nirvÄá¹‡a.
As it is said:
Because of upholding the precepts, the mind does not regret, and one attains liberation and nirvÄá¹‡a.

The practitioner contemplates the pure precepts, the precepts without deficiency, the precepts without violation, the precepts without holes, the precepts without mixture, the autonomous precepts, the precepts without attachment, and the precepts praised by the wise.
Being free from flaws is called the pure precepts.
What is meant by not lacking in precepts?
Among the five precepts, excluding the four grave precepts, violating the remaining grave precepts is called lacking, and violating the other offenses is called breaking.
Furthermore, bodily offenses are called lacking, and verbal offenses are called breaking.
Furthermore, grave offenses are called lacking, and minor offenses are called breaking.
A wholesome mind directed towards nirvana, not allowing afflictions and various evil thoughts to enter, is called not perforated.
Directed towards both nirvana and the world, this is called mixed.
Following the precepts, not following external conditions.
Upholding these pure precepts like a self-sufficient person who is not subject to others, not bound by the fetters of craving, this is called autonomous precepts.
Not giving rise to afflictions such as craving and pride towards the precepts, knowing the true nature of the precepts, and not grasping at these precepts,
If one grasps at these precepts, it is like a person in prison, bound by shackles and chains, who is pardoned but is still bound by golden chains.
People are bound by the afflictions of love and desire, like being in prison;
Although they leave the household life, they are attached to the precepts, like being bound by golden chains.

If practitioners know that the precepts are the cause and condition for attaining the undefiled [fruits of the path], and do not give rise to attachment, then they are liberated, unfettered, and this is called not grasping at the precepts.
The precepts praised by the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Pratyekabuddhas, and Sravakas, if one practices these precepts and uses these precepts, this is called the precepts praised by the wise.

The precepts of non-Buddhists, such as the precepts of cows, deer, dogs, rakshasa ghosts, dumbness, and deafness, are not praised by the wise, and are meaningless suffering without any good retribution.

Furthermore, that which is praised by the wise refers to the unbroken and indestructible pure precepts among the three kinds of precepts. Relying on these precepts, one attains true wisdom, which is the precepts praised by the sages.
Pure precepts are of three kinds:
As the Buddha said, right speech, right action, and right livelihood.
The meaning of these three actions is as explained in the Eightfold Noble Path, which should be explained in detail here.
Question:

If upholding precepts is the cause and condition for meditative concentration, and meditative concentration is the cause and condition for wisdom, why is wisdom placed first, precepts in the middle, and concentration at the end in the Eightfold Noble Path?
Answer:
The method of traveling should first be to see the path with the eyes and then proceed, and one should be diligent when walking;
when practicing diligently, one should always keep in mind the instructions of the guide;
having kept in mind, one should single-mindedly proceed on the path, not following the wrong path.
Right view is also like this. First, with right wisdom, one observes that the five aggregates of clinging are all suffering, which is called suffering;
Suffering arises from the combination of afflictions such as craving. This is called the cause.
The cessation of afflictions such as craving is called nirvana.
Contemplating the eight aspects in this way is called the path. This is called right view.
At this time, the practitioner's mind definitely knows that the false and deceptive world can be abandoned, and that nirvana, the true Dharma, can be attained. This is called right view.
Knowing and seeing this matter, the power of the mind is not yet great, and one is not yet able to put it into practice.
Contemplating and deliberating, one activates right view and enables it to gain power. This is called right thought.
Since wisdom has arisen, one wishes to proclaim it with words, so next come right speech, right action, and right livelihood, which are precepts.
When practicing, one's diligence is not lax, and one does not allow oneself to dwell in the concentrations of form and formlessness. This is called right effort.
Using this right view to contemplate the four truths, always keeping them in mind without forgetting:
One should know that all afflictions are thieves and should be abandoned.
Right view and so forth are my true companions, and I should follow them. This is called right mindfulness.

In the four truths, the mind is concentrated and not scattered, not allowing it to go towards the formless concentrations, but single-mindedly heading towards nirvana. This is called right concentration.
This is the initial attainment of wholesome contaminated [dharmas], called the meaning of the dharmas of heat, summit, and patience;
Gradually progressing, the initial, middle, and final minds.
Entering the uncontaminated mind quickly, complete in a single mind, without the distinction of a sequence of earlier and later.
Associated with right view, right thought, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration, the three kinds of precepts follow this part by part.
Right view distinguishes good and bad and benefits as its function;
Right thought activates right view as its function;
Right speech and so forth uphold this wisdom and various merits, not allowing them to be scattered and lost;
Right effort drives and encourages it to quickly progress without stopping;
Right mindfulness, which is the practice of the seven factors, is to remember without forgetting;
Right concentration, which purifies the mind, makes it untainted and unconfused, and enables right view and the seven factors to be accomplished;
Just as a lamp in a windless room shines brightly and clearly.
Thus, the undefiled precepts, being in the Eightfold Noble Path, are also praised by the wise.
Question:
The undefiled precepts should be praised by the wise, but why praise the defiled precepts?
Answer:
The defiled precepts resemble the undefiled, and in accordance with the undefiled, they are co-practitioners. For this reason, the wise praise them together.

Just as among thieves, if someone defects and comes to me, although they are thieves, now they come to me, and I will accept them. They can be used to break through the thieves. Why not think of them?

The thieves of afflictions dwell in the city of the three realms. The wholesome roots of contaminated precepts, such as the heat stage, summit stage, patience stage, and highest worldly dharmas, are different from other contaminated dharmas, so practitioners enjoy them.
For this reason, they destroy the thieves of the afflictions and attain the undefiled dharma wealth of the acceptance of the truth of suffering. For this reason, they are praised by the wise.
This is called mindfulness of precepts.
Mindfulness of relinquishment has two kinds of relinquishment:
First, giving, second, relinquishing afflictions.
Giving relinquishment has two kinds:
First, material giving, second, giving the Dharma.
The combination of the three kinds of relinquishment is called relinquishment.
Because material giving is the root of all wholesome dharmas, practitioners think like this:
Because of the above four mindfulnesses, one can cure the illness of afflictions. Now, for what reasons can one attain these four mindfulnesses?
It is because of the causes and conditions of having made few offerings to the Three Jewels in past and present lives.
Why is it so?
Because sentient beings have not known how to make offerings to the Three Jewels in the world without beginning, their blessings are all exhausted and extinguished.
The Three Jewels have immeasurable Dharma, therefore, giving also does not end, and one will surely attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
Furthermore, when the Buddhas of the past first gave rise to the aspiration, they all took few or many offerings as the causes and conditions;
As the Buddha said:
This giving is the initial cause and condition that assists the Way.
Furthermore, human life is impermanent, and wealth is like lightning. If a person does not beg, one should still give, let alone when begging but not giving.
Therefore, one should give, making it a cause and condition that assists the Way.
Furthermore, wealth is the cause and condition for various afflictions and sinful karma;
If precepts, meditation, wisdom, and various wholesome dharmas are the causes and conditions for nirvÄá¹‡a.
For this reason, one should even abandon one's own wealth, let alone not give to a field of excellent blessings?
For example, there were two brothers who each carried ten pounds of gold on their way, with no other companions.
The elder brother thought:
Why don't I kill my younger brother and take the gold?
In this vast wilderness, no one will know.
The younger brother also had the thought of killing his elder brother and taking the gold.
Each of the brothers had evil thoughts, and their words and glances were all different.
The brothers then realized on their own and gave rise to remorse:
We are not human, what are we different from beasts?
We were born as brothers, yet for a little gold we gave rise to evil thoughts!
The brothers went together to the edge of a deep pool, and the elder brother threw the gold into the water.
The younger brother said:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
The younger brother then also threw the gold into the water.
The elder brother also said:ğŸ”½Excellent!
Excellent!
The brothers asked each other, Why do you say 'excellent'?
They each answered,
Because of this gold, we gave rise to unwholesome thoughts, wanting to harm each other;
Now that we have discarded it, we say 'excellent'!
The two of them each said the same.
Therefore, know that wealth is the cause and condition for evil thoughts, and one should always give it away!
How much more so for giving, which brings great blessings, and yet not giving?
As it is said:
Giving is called a treasure house, and also a good friend,
Benefiting each other from beginning to end, nothing can destroy it.
Giving is a dense canopy that can block the rain of hunger and thirst;
Giving is a sturdy ship that can ferry one across the ocean of poverty.
Stinginess is an inauspicious sign, it gives rise to worry and fear;
Washing it with the water of giving, then it becomes a source of blessings and benefits.
Stingy people who do not clothe or feed themselves will have no joy or happiness throughout their lives;
Although they may have wealth and possessions, they are no different from the poor and destitute.
The house of a miser is like a grave in a cemetery,
Those who seek [wealth] avoid it from afar, and in the end there are none who approach it.
Thus, a miserly and greedy person is cast aside by the wise;
Even if their vital energy has not yet been exhausted, they are no different from the dead.
A miser has no blessings or wisdom, and is unyielding in giving;ğŸ”½When about to fall into the pit of death, they cling to their possessions with regret and resentment;
They will weep and depart alone, and the fire of remorse will burn their bodies.
Those who delight in giving are at ease and happy, and will never have such suffering.
Those who cultivate giving have their fame fill the ten directions,
They are loved and respected by the wise, and enter the assembly without fear,
When their life ends, they are reborn in the heavens, and will eventually attain nirvana!
In this way, various kinds of scolding of stinginess and praising of giving are called mindfulness of material giving.
What is mindfulness of giving the Dharma?
The practitioner thinks like this:
The benefits of giving the Dharma are very great!
Because of giving the Dharma, all the Buddha's disciples attain the Way.
Furthermore, the Buddha said:
Among the two kinds of giving, giving the Dharma is the foremost.
Why is it so?
The fruits and rewards of material giving are limited, but the fruits and rewards of giving the Dharma are immeasurable.
Material giving results in rewards in the desire realm;
Giving the Dharma results in rewards in the three realms, and also in rewards beyond the three realms.

If one does not seek fame, profit, or power, but only studies the Buddha's path, cultivates great compassion, and delivers sentient beings from the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death, this is called pure giving of the Dharma.
If it is not so, it is like trading in the marketplace.
Furthermore, material giving, the more one gives, the fewer one's possessions become;
The gift of Dharma is more abundant, and the Dharma further increases.
The gift of material things is an old practice for immeasurable lives, but the gift of Dharma is a new practice that has not yet been obtained for the sacred Dharma.
The gift of material things can only save from hunger, thirst, cold, heat, and other illnesses, but the gift of Dharma can eliminate the ninety-eight afflictions and other illnesses.
In this way, the gift of material things and the gift of Dharma are distinguished by various causes and conditions. Practitioners should remember the gift of Dharma.
Question:
What is the gift of Dharma?
Answer:
The Buddha's teachings in the twelve divisions of the canon, when one expounds them to others with a pure mind for the sake of merit, this is called the gift of Dharma.
Moreover, using the power of spiritual penetrations to enable others to attain the Way is also called the gift of Dharma.
As it is said in the NetraguhyapradÄ«pa SÅ«tra:
There are those who see the Buddha's radiance and attain the Way, and those who are born in the heavens.
In this way, although one does not speak with the mouth, because it enables others to attain the Dharma, it is also called the gift of Dharma.

This Dharma giving should observe the nature of sentient beings' minds, the amount of afflictions, and the sharpness or dullness of their wisdom, and should expound the Dharma according to what is beneficial.
It is like taking medicine according to one's illness, which is beneficial.ğŸ”½Some have heavy lust, some have heavy anger, some have heavy delusion, and some have two or three mixed.

For those with heavy lust, one should expound the contemplation of impurity; for those with heavy anger, one should expound the mind of loving-kindness; for those with heavy delusion, one should expound the profound dependent origination; for those with two mixed, one should expound two contemplations; for those with three mixed, one should expound three contemplations.
If a person does not know the characteristics of an illness and mistakenly administers medicine, the illness will worsen.
If one clings to the characteristics of sentient beings, one should expound that there are only five aggregates, and there is no self within them;
if one says there are no characteristics of sentient beings, then one should expound that the five aggregates continue, to prevent them from falling into annihilation.
For those seeking wealth and pleasure, one should expound giving;
for those wishing to be reborn in the heavens, one should expound upholding precepts;
For those who lack much in the human realm, he speaks of heavenly matters.
For those who are troubled by household life, he speaks of the Dharma of leaving the household life;
For those who are attached to wealth and household life, he speaks of the five precepts for householders;
If they do not delight in the world, he speaks of the three Dharma seals:
Impermanence, no-self, and nirvana.
In accordance with the sutra teachings, he elaborates on the principles and parables, adorns the Dharma, and speaks for sentient beings.
For these various kinds of benefits, one should think of the gift of Dharma.
Abandoning afflictions means completely cutting off the three bonds up to the ninety-eight latent afflictions, which is called abandonment.
Thinking of abandoning this Dharma is like abandoning a poisonous snake or like abandoning shackles, and one attains peace and joy.
Furthermore, thinking of abandoning afflictions is also included in the recollection of the Dharma.
Question:
If it is included in the recollection of the Dharma, why is it now spoken of again?
Answer:
Abandoning all afflictions is a subtle and difficult Dharma to attain, unsurpassed and immeasurable, therefore it is explained separately.
Moreover, mindfulness of the Dharma is different from mindfulness of equanimity.
Mindfulness of the Dharma is to be mindful that the Buddha's Dharma is subtle and supreme among all dharmas;
Mindfulness of equanimity is to be mindful that all afflictions and evil are to be abandoned.
The aspects of practice are different, this is the difference.
For these various reasons, practitioners should be mindful of equanimity.
Being mindful of equanimity is to fear giving rise to conceit in the beginning stages of cultivating concentration and wisdom.
Being mindful of the gods refers to the gods of the four heavenly kings up to the gods who delight in creating.
Question:
The Buddha's disciples should single-mindedly be mindful of the Buddha and the Buddha's teachings. Why be mindful of the gods?
Answer:
Knowing the causes and conditions of the karma of giving, one experiences the rich and blissful rewards of the heavens. For this reason, one is mindful of the gods.
Moreover, the Buddha himself explained the causes and conditions of these eight mindfulnesses.
Those who contemplate the heavens should contemplate thus:
There are the Four Heavenly Kings, and these heavens are born there due to five wholesome causes and conditions:
Faith in the retribution of good and evil, upholding precepts, hearing the good Dharma, practicing generosity, and cultivating wisdom;
I also have these five dharmas, and for this reason I rejoice and say:
'The heavens are born in places of wealth and happiness due to these five dharmas, and I also have them;
I wish to be born there, and I can be born there, but I do not accept it because the blessings of the heavens are impermanent.'
Up to the Paranirmita-vaÅ›avartin Heaven, it is the same.
Question:
In the three realms, there are many pure heavens. Why only contemplate the desire heavens?
Answer:
In the ÅšrÄvaka teachings, it is said to contemplate the desire realm heavens, but in the MahÄyÄna, it is said to contemplate all the heavens of the three realms.
When the practitioner has not yet attained the Way, their mind may be attached to the five desires of the human realm. For this reason, the Buddha taught contemplating the heavens.
If one can cut off sexual desire, one will be reborn in the heavens of the two upper realms;
If one cannot cut off sexual desire, one will be reborn in the six heavens of desire, where there are subtle, fine, and pure five desires.

Although the Buddha does not want people to be reborn and experience the five desires again, there are sentient beings who are not yet able to enter nirvana. It is for these sentient beings that he teaches the contemplation of the heavens.
It is like a prince who is standing in a dangerous place and cannot be saved. He wants to throw himself to the ground;
The king has people spread out thick cotton mats, so that when he falls, he will not die, and it is better than falling to the ground.
Furthermore, there are four kinds of heavens:
Name heavens, born heavens, pure heavens, and born pure heavens.
Name heavens are like the king of a country who is called the Son of Heaven.
Born heavens are from the Four Heavenly Kings up to the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception.
Pure heavens are the sages born among humans.

As for being born in the pure heavens, among the heavens of the three realms, one is born as an arhat, namely a stream-enterer, a once-returner who returns to their family, or a non-returner who attains the path of an arhat in the heavens.
As for being born in the pure heavens, in the form realm there are five types of non-returners who do not return to this realm but attain arhatship there.

In the formless realm there is one type of non-returner who, having left the form realm, is born in the formless realm and there cultivates the uncontaminated path, attains arhatship, and enters nirvana.
There are two types of heavens to be mindful of:
The heavens of rebirth and the pure heavens.
Heavens such as these are called the heavens to be mindful of.
As for being mindful of anÄpÄna, it is as explained in the DhyÄna SÅ«tra.
As for being mindful of death, there are two types of death:
First, natural death; second, death due to external causes.
The practitioner is always mindful of these two types of death:
If this body is not killed by others, it will certainly die by itself;
In this way, in conditioned phenomena, one should not give rise to a mind of faith and immortality even for the time of a finger snap.

This body is always subject to death, it does not wait for old age, one should not rely on this body of various worries and misfortunes, and give rise to a mind hoping for peace and immortality. This mind is given rise to by a deluded person.
The four great elements in the body each harm each other. It is like a person holding a box of poisonous snakes. How can a wise person consider it peaceful?

If one protects the exhaled breath, it will certainly return to the inhaled breath, and if one protects the inhaled breath, it will return to the exhaled breath. If one sleeps, one will certainly be able to return to awakening again. This is all difficult and certain!
Why is this?
Because there are many enemies, both inside and outside the body.
As it is said:
Some die in the womb, some die at birth,
Some die in middle age, some die when old.
It is like when fruits ripen, they fall due to various conditions.
You should seek to be free from this, the evil thief of death.
This thief is difficult to trust, when it abandons you, then you are at ease.
Even if there were a greatly wise person, with unsurpassed majestic virtue and power;
There would be no one before or after, in the present there is no one who can escape.
There are no skillful words of apology, no way to seek release;
There is no place to resist, from which one can escape;
It is not by upholding pure precepts, nor by diligence that one can be released.

Question:
The Dharma is the teacher of the Buddhas of the three times. Why is the Buddha placed first in the contemplations?
What is the sequence of these eight contemplations?
Answer:
Although the Dharma is the teacher of the Buddhas of the ten directions and three times, the Buddha is able to manifest this Dharma, and his merit is great.
It is like a treasure mountain in the Himalayas, with a wish-fulfilling jewel and various treasures on the summit.
Many people want to climb it, but some turn back halfway, while others turn back after getting close.
There was a great virtuous king who felt compassion for sentient beings and built a great staircase for them;
People of all ages, even children as young as seven, were able to climb the mountain and take whatever wish-fulfilling jewels and other treasures they desired.

The Buddha is also like this. The mountain of real marks of dharmas in the world, the ninety-six kinds of non-Buddhist paths are all unable to obtain, up to the Brahma Heaven King seeking the real marks of dharmas is also unable to obtain, how much more so for other people!

Moreover, it is because of the Buddha that the Dharma appears in the world, and it is because of the Dharma that there is the Sangha.
The practitioner thinks:

I must eliminate all coarse and subtle evil deeds of body and speech.
Therefore, the precepts are explained in sequence.
Moreover, how is it that there are seven assemblies?
It is because there are precepts.

In order to eliminate mental evil and break greed and stinginess, one should think of giving. In order to make the recipient happy, one should break anger. In order to believe in the fruits of blessings and rewards, one should break wrong views.
Dwelling in the Dharma of precepts and giving, one dwells in the ten wholesome paths and departs from the ten unwholesome paths.
The ten wholesome paths have two kinds of fruits:
If the superior practitioner attains a pure heavenly rebirth, the middling practitioner attains rebirth in the heavens.
For this reason, morality and giving are followed by mindfulness of the heavens.
By practicing meditation, one attains the two kinds of heavens.
Extinguishing all evil thoughts, only accumulating wholesome dharmas, concentrating the mind in one place;
Therefore, mindfulness of the heavens is followed by mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation.
Mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation can extinguish all evil thoughts, like rain extinguishing dust;
Seeing the breath coming and going, knowing the body is fragile, due to the coming and going of the breath, the body is able to exist;
Therefore, mindfulness of inhalation and exhalation is followed by mindfulness of death.
Furthermore, the practitioner may sometimes rely on the seven mindfulnesses, attached to these merits, and a lazy mind arises. At this time, one should be mindful of death;
The matter of death is always in front, how can one be lazy and attached to this dharma-love?
